results.title: What goes around comes around
results.creator_credit: Jeremy Ducker and Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television
results.brief_description: When Fabian, a reclusive young man who lives and works in a laundrette, meets Lolita, there is only one obstacle to his new found love - his mother who lives upstairs. Gradually he conquers her jealousy and wrath as well as his own insecurities as Lolita teaches him more about himself and his relations with others. Lolita collapses stereotypes and frees him from the suffocating influence of his mother. This is a light hearted and comical film with none the less powerful messages.

results.title: Hidden depths
results.brief_description: A three part series on the possible causes, symptoms and treatment for depression as practised by psychologists and mental health support groups in London. The programs feature both professionals who treat depression and sufferers of the complaint.
results.description: A three part series on the possible causes, symptoms and treatment for depression as practised by psychologists and mental health support groups in London. The programs feature both professionals who treat depression and sufferers of the complaint.

results.title: Fighting depression
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Hidden depths”.
The director of MIND in Camden, Dr. David Hill, outlines the services offered by his drop-in centre for former patients of psychiatric hospitals, emphasising the need to raise self-esteem so that patients can successfully re-enter normal life without suffering from depression. His methods of counselling, as well as those employed by the women running Women’s Action for Mental Health, are shown. Both organisations concentrate on encouraging and empowering the depressed person through attentive listening, emotional support and client centred group activities.

results.title: What depresses me ...
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Hidden depths”.
Psychotherapy, both in groups and singly, offers those suffering from depression a non-drug solution to their problems. In this program sufferers, psychologists and counsellors discuss the causes of depression (low self-esteem, childhood trauma from physical and sexual abuse, loneliness) and the value of psychotherapy and counselling. Professor David Smail outlines the three stages of therapy and stresses the importance of accurately assessing the limitations on resources for change available to each client and an awareness of the potential for client over-dependence on the comfort offered by the therapist.

results.title: Understandably depressed
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Hidden depths”.
Depression is a state where nothing outside is of any interest any longer (Ruley) “It’s like not feeling quite alive” What exactly is depression? Is it a physical illness or a state of mind? What are the symptoms of depression? Are some people or families more prone to depression than others? Does medication help, or merely prolong the cure? Using the experiences of two depressives, Ruley and John and the opinions of clinical psychologist, Professor David Smail and GP, Dr. Brian Harris, this program attempts to provide some answers on this condition which can affect up to one in four people at some time in their lives.

results.title: What are you running for? = Qusque tu vas de meme?
results.creator_credit: Jacques Bobet, Francois Seguillon and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The running of the Fernand Grenier Race, an annual 67 kilometer relay foot race between the villages of La Guadeloupe and Lac Megantic, Quebec, during the first weeked in October. Competitors come from all parts of the province to run in the five-hour marathon. This film covers the entire race, often employing multi-image techniques to show more than one runner at a time. The film has no commentary.

results.title: Top guns and toxic whales
results.creator_credit: Lawrence Moore, Robbie Stamp, Better World Society, Central TV and Television Trust for the Environment
results.brief_description: Anthony Hopkins narrates this documentary which explores the issue of environmental security, and the link between ecological crises and military expenditure. The conflict bewteen massive military expenditure and the human problems of population growth, energy source depletion, and third world debt is explored.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lawrence Moore, Robbie Stamp, Better World Society, Central TV and Television Trust for the Environment

results.title: Top priority
results.creator_credit: Ishu Patel and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Set in an unspecified Third World country, this animated film, based on a short story by Enver Carim, suggests that “top priority” means different things to governments and to the governed. A drought-stricken family maintains a long and desperate vigil for a cloud of dust on the horizon signalling the arrival of irrigation pipes and pump. They are rewarded with a military convoy instead. Its top priority is a border war with a neighboring state, not pipes for the life-saving water the family must have.

results.title: Too many Captain Cooks
results.brief_description: This film seeks to replace the stereotypes promoted by the non-Aboriginal history of white settlement in Australia which usually begins with the ‘discoveries’ of Captain Cook. Here history is re-told from the point-of-view of the colonised: ‘Aboriginals discovered Captain Cook’. In Northern Australia white people are referred to as ‘Captain Cooks’. The film’s form is sensitive to the telling of tribal history of Captain Cook as spoken by Paddy Wambarranga of the Rembarrnga tribe in Arnhem Land. This history is also represented by images of Aboriginal art. Rembarrnga and Kriol dialogue with English subtitles.

results.title: Too dirty for a woman
results.creator_credit: Diane Beaudry, Kathleen Shannon, Signe Johansson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: In Labrador City, Newfoundland, women have been hired by the Iron Ore Company as truck drivers, engineers, laborers, geologists, warehouse workers, machinists, and mechanics. Living in a company town, they are pioneers in their own community. The women talk about their non-traditional jobs, their new feelings of independence, and how their families’ lives have been affected. One of the consequences is that husbands now share household chores. There are, however, obstacles to be overcome before women can apply for a job, such as the scarcity of day care facilities and a lack of public transportation. Strong visuals show women at work driving a 130-tonne truck, surveying a blast pattern for a drill, or acting as the first female foreman, alias foreperson.
